content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Adnoddau Dysgu/ Learning Objects</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/3709" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle/> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/3709</id> <updated>2015-03-20T01:40:06Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-20T01:40:06Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Giving a clear picture: Metadata use in repositories to represent still images</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/4083" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Payne, Hannah</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/4083</id> <updated>2010-02-24T16:48:42Z</updated> <published>2010-02-19T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Giving a clear picture: Metadata use in repositories to represent still images Payne, Hannah The purpose of this learning object is to consider metadata use in repository records when relating to still image items. Repositories are increasingly being tasked to store all research items produced by an institution, within all subject areas. Within the creative arts, research objects can take many forms including 3D artefacts as well as 2D images. The challenge for repository administrators is how best to represent these items within a digital repository. This learning object will explore how metadata can best be used to represent still image items within a repository whether the image is the original item to be described or the representation of that item. The pages of this learning resource are packaged as a zip file. Your internet browser should automatically recognise this and unpack the file. If not, you can choose an internet browser from the presented options to open the files within. Alternatively, you may need a zip utility to unpackage the file. </summary> <dc:date>2010-02-19T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Metadata in repositories: An overview</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/4082" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Knowles, Jackie</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/4082</id> <updated>2010-02-24T16:45:29Z</updated> <published>2010-02-19T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Metadata in repositories: An overview Knowles, Jackie The purpose of this learning object is to provide some basic introductory information about metadata and its use within an institutional repository. It aims to: explain what metadata is; explain the importance and purpose of metadata in a repository context; outline the key metadata standard in use within repositories; re-enforce the importance of using metadata standards within a repository to enable interoperability and harvesting. The pages of this learning resource are packaged as a zip file. Your internet browser should automatically recognise this and unpack the file. If not, you can choose an internet browser from the presented options to open the files within. Alternatively, you may need a zip utility to unpackage the file. </summary> <dc:date>2010-02-19T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Multimedia Deposits: Complications and Considerations with Intellectual Property Rights</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/3710" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Payne, Hannah</name> </author> <author> <name>Shipley, Lauren</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/3710</id> <updated>2010-02-24T16:50:20Z</updated> <published>2009-11-26T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Multimedia Deposits: Complications and Considerations with Intellectual Property Rights Payne, Hannah; Shipley, Lauren The purpose of this learning object is to explore the Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) that may be within multimedia items, and to highlight some of the complications and considerations that need to be taken into account before a deposit of this type can be made into a repository. The pages of this learning resource are packaged as a zip file. Your internet browser should automatically recognise this and unpack the file. If not, you can choose an internet browser from the presented options to open the files within. Alternatively, you may need a zip utility to unpackage the file. </summary> <dc:date>2009-11-26T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
